title: Part A: Thesis
stimulusHtml:
The thesis may be more than one sentence, provided the sentences are in close proximity.

The thesis may appear anywhere within the essay.

For a thesis to be defensible, the passage must include at least minimal evidence that could be used to support that thesis; however, the student need not cite that evidence to earn the thesis point.

The thesis may establish a line of reasoning that structures the essay, but it needn’t do so to earn the thesis point.

A thesis that meets the criteria can be awarded the point whether or not the rest of the response successfully conveys that line of reasoning.
descriptions: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
Responds to the prompt with a defensible thesis that analyzes the writer’s rhetorical choices.

title: Part B: Evidence AND Commentary
stimulusHtml:
To earn the fourth point in this row, the response may observe multiple instances of the same rhetorical choice if each instance further contributes to the argument, purpose, or message of the passage.

Writing that suffers from grammatical and/or mechanical errors that interfere with communication cannot earn the fourth point in this row.

The response meets both of the following criteria:

title: Part C: Sophistication
stimulusHtml:
This point should be awarded only if the sophistication of thought or complex understanding is part of the argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

Responses that earn this point may demonstrate sophistication of thought and/or a complex understanding of the rhetorical situation by doing any of the following:

1. Explaining the significance or relevance of the writer’s rhetorical choices (given the rhetorical situation).

2. Explaining a purpose or function of the passage’s complexities or tensions.

3. Employing a style that is consistently vivid and persuasive.

As students strengthen their skills in developing textually substantiated arguments, encourage them to approach the writing process with the elements of sophistication outlined above in mind. You may wish in your feedback on student essays to share particular instances of sophisticated thinking or pinpoint opportunities for developing greater complexity in their arguments.
descriptions: Response does not demonstrate sophistication of thought and/or a complex understanding of the rhetorical situation.
Response demonstrates sophistication of thought and/or a complex understanding of the rhetorical situation.
